unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Sports Drinks: Expected Count
question_text:
Suppose a random survey was taken in a large urban high school to determine if vending machine location affects whether sports drinks are more likely to be ordered.
A large single sample of size n = $500$ was taken over the last week. In the cafeteria, $78$ of the $165$ drinks purchased were sports drinks. In the gym, $98$ of the $157$ drinks purchased were sports drinks, and in the auditorium, $54$ of the $178$ drinks purchased were sports drinks.
The expected number of people who did NOT order sports drinks in the gym is?
solution:
Expected counts can be found by putting the two-way table into a matrix on a TI-$83/84$ calculator, running a chi-squared test, and then going into Matrix B to find the expected counts.

Otherwise, by hand, expected counts for any cell in a matrix is:

$$\dfrac{\text{(row total)} \times \text{(column total)}}{\text{(table total)}}$$

The matrix would look like the table below:

The expected count would be:

$$(98 + 59) \times \dfrac{(87 + 59 + 124)}{500} = 84.78$$

Never round expected counts, as these are used in the chi-squared test statistic calculation.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'A'.
